title: Dust Chute for Delta Miter Saw
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Dust shroud / dust chute replacement part for a Delta 3802L Type 1 (might also fit many of the Porter Cable brands). This is the piece the guides saw dust and chips up into dust collection hose. I wasn't able to find a replacement part that on-line or from manufacturer, so decided to make my own.

Will allow full movement of the saw without interference. But as of 2/17/2017 it has only been in operation for about a week so still testing.

My OEM part shattered about a year ago and have been doing without so just took good measurements and created a totally new version based on some paper models. This may not really look anything like the original, but I think does a better job.

Designed in Fusion 360 and I'll post some design files if asked for. Should be easy to modify for different version of the saw.

Update - Oct, 2017
Still functioning perfectly! Showing no signs of wear, even when printed in PLA!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

Turn object so it is on its side for easy printing

Should require little to no changes from default settings to print properly.
Original is printed at 0.2mm layers and when turned on its side, the layers alight with the direction of chip and air flow, so might be possible to print with larger layers and have not difference in function. I would suggest printed with 6 wide perimeter.

Current part is PLA and works great.
OEM part shattered about a year ago, so this is a from scratch redesign of a dust chute for this saw.

description.text: This plate was designed by me to use in conjunction with a window air duct, to make extraction for a 3D printer using ABS.

Just a simple cover to replace the broken one. I didn't find a model with holes, so I designed it by myself.
Modeled in FreeCAD, (source file included here), sliced in Slic3r, printed by a Prusa I3.

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

1 year ago my farther died from Alzheimers (dementia) but one thing that he did like to do was sit and watch the birds... so... print one out for yourselves but also print out a second one for someone with Alzheimers or take one to a care home or nursing home so others can enjoy.
im not the best at designing and drawing but its functional and it prints.
i printed at a layer height of .3 and an infill of 20% .. took about 5 hours but for a better finish print at a lower layer height.
just fill from the base then screw on the cap and flip it over quickly.. there is also a base that can be screwed to the bottom so it can sit on tables or on the floor.

if everyone just printed out one and took it to a care home it will make someone happy and prove to people that 3d printing can be used for something good.
Thank you

comments.text: I love this concept... That being said, the "Windows" version has tons of geometry errors that make the surface quality absolutely horrible. I have had no luck repairing the upper and lower parts of the case with Meshmixer or Netfabb. It makes the model slightly better, but it is so full of bad geometry that there is no reliable way to fix it. At first I thought the issues were isolated to the screw holes in the front of the case halves. Since I imported it into Meshmixer, I found many areas all over the model that are the cause of the surface quality issues. You won't see it in a slice preview, but the issues are repeatable print for print. I encourage the designer to export another file to try to see if the issues could be overcome. It's a great design, but needs a better export to STL.

comments.text:
FYI: If you're having problems slicing this with Simplify3D, try Mesh -> Separate Connected Surfaces.
Some of the parts, like v5_Small_Volume_1kg_BASE_2, have embedded Logos that are separate meshes and don't show up during printing. But it messes up S3D slicing which can lead to failed prints, or poor structure quality around that logo.
Once the meshes are separated, S3D can slice it properly and generate clean gcode.
Hope this helps.

description.text: This is a relatively simple design for replacing the drawer rail slides on the Y axis.

Print the Y base and rod adapters in ABS.  I printed the spacers in ABS, too.  
Print the cable management in PLA or you won't be able to use ABS juice on your bed.  
I printed everyting with 30% infill.  
I drilled out the rod adapters after printing to be a snug but not tight fit on the rod so that I could slide it in place as needed.  
If you don't use a spring based leveling system, you only lose 3mm of height over stock and you retain the full usable heated bed.  I found that I only needed to add a washer under one corner to get acceptable level and I'm not sure I needed that.

comments.text: Thank you for this. I contacted RoBo 3D recently and inquired about getting the upgrade kit without the heated bed. They obviously didn't want to do that because they wouldn't be getting the money. This is going to be my weekend upgrade.

title: Magnetic Screen Cover for Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
Have you actually ever wanted to go to sleep with this damn printer in your room? Are you constantly hassled by having to get cataracts removed from staring at this miniature sun-in-an-LCD?

Here is a solution that only requires magnets!

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm (go lower if you please)

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Don't be an idiot like I was and end up smooshing the first layer and making it look like crap. Printing upside down is usually your best bet for text.
Just stick in some neodymium magnets (1cm diameter by 2mm thick) and you're good to go!
SolidWorks! Literally it. AMF, STL, and SLDPRT files are included. I can even give STEP files if you want.

comments.text: nice model, easy to put on / take off and the magnets are a perfect fit.

comments.text: If it is a functional glock, with every component included and is actually accurate to scale, then the barrel, firing pin, and a few other portions, can be swapped out for real ones, which doesn't require a person to have a background check in order to buy, and thus can create a fully functioning, 'real' gun. Sure it wont last more than a few rounds, if at all, but U.S. law states that it is illegal to supply functioning 'guns' without a proper background check, and while this may be plastic, and have plastic internals, if it is 'functioning' as in you can rack a bullet into the chamber, pull the trigger and hear a 'click' from the plastic firing pin hitting the plastic bullet casing, then it is, by definition, providing a fully functioning gun to the public without a background check... There is a reason why you can't just search up '3D printable 1911' or 'SIG 320' and easily find ones that are 'functioning'.... because its A) illegal, and B) insanely hard to reproduce...
comments.author: artadams

comments.text:
You are completely incorrect.
1) this is no different than a toy gun you buy at the store.
2) it is not against federal law to transfer a firearm in a private party transaction without a background check.
3) this is a digital file and not a physical gun.
4) even if this worked it's not considered a firearm until its printed.
5) it is completely legal for someone to manufacture a firearm for themselves as long as:
a) they are not a restricted person
B) they don't have the intention of selling it (if they decide they don't want it down the road they can sell it)
C) it is not an nfa regulated item (if it is a form 4 must be filed with the atf and received back before doing anything).

title: Modified j-head e3dv5 support and cooler.

description.text:
Just a little mod to the original support designed by shawdreamer.
With this one, you can gain more space on the right side of the nozzle.
You need to reprint the cooler as well, because the one from the original design won't fit anymore.
I printed this with fluorescent yellow abs from Hobbyking, 30% 3d honeycomb infill, 3 perimeter and 3 solid infill in the top and bottom.
As you can see in the picture, I use this one on the original carriage and I have already used it for 100+ hours of printing.
Edit: The cooler don't have holes for screwing the fan because the 40mm fan I use have the holes a little offset from the standard. I drill the holes, directly on the flange and the use 2 3x15mm self tapping screw in diagonal.

comments.text: Out of curiosity, did you end up using the same extruder motor and if so, where did you place it?
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text:
Yes, I used the same motor that was on the old extruder.
I mounted it on the top of the printer using this support https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1685389.
You can mount where you like, but I suggest to mount it on top, and if you have encased the printer, mount it outside.

title: Ventilador de Capa Radial - CTC Prusa I3 Pro B

description.text:
Después de varios intentos por utilizar ventiladores de capa radiales que existen en thingiverse, he decidido (a pesar de basarme en diseños que ya existen, aunque no es un remix) fabricarme el ventilador que yo necesito.

Es para la CTC Prusa i3 Pro B y he usado el siguiente ventilador:

http://www.ebay.es/itm/252651794370?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

La impresión no necesita Raft ni soporte, solo una base de 8 mms para que pegue bien a la cama. Por lo demás no tiene dificultades.

Para los conectores de los ventiladores use estos:

http://www.ebay.es/itm/152382980140?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

y soldé los cables para que pueda desconectar el ventilador de capa cuando use ABS.

author: Codenamebravo

description.text: Steering Wheel for RC model

I noticed my Ikea Lack table was a bit wobbly, so I designed this bracket.

You will need 4 brackets in total, one for each leg. They are designed for size 6 screws, with enough holes for 7 in each bracket, which is definitely overkill, so you can probably get away with fewer.

I have included models that have the following on each hole:
-An 82 degree countersink, designed for standard wood screws.
-A more shallow countersink, designed for drywall screws.
-No countersink, designed for normal pan head screws.

These brackets paired with a foam mat below the table have reduced vibration caused by the printer almost entirely.

title: CraftBot Hold Down Clip for PRINTinZ Plate

description.text:
This is a printable clip for a CraftBot printer bed used to secure the rear edge of a PRINTinZ Printer plate. It is used together with M3 thumb screws along the front edge. The thickness of PRINTinZ Plates varies slightly from one plate to another so the clip may need to be scaled by +/-0.5mm to make the opening slightly bigger or smaller to fit your individual PRINTinZ Plate. This can be scaled in your slicer. The clip Is installed between the rear bed springs and the bottom of the printer bed. See the following video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4AlIO3GmyjU&feature=youtu.be

https://www.printinz.com/printinz-plate-3d-printer-bed-upgrade/

author: Burroughs05

print_settings.Notes:: Recommended to print on raft for much more accurate edge than brim.

description.text:
This is a minimal cross style case for iPhone 6/6s.
It provides essential protection for the phone landing at any angle.

The primary purpose of designing this case is making sure the arm grabbing the phone won't break.
Therefore the case was designed as two parts, each printed vertically to optimize the strength.

PS:

  • screen protector was not considered as I don't use it.
  • recommended to print at 0.1mm layer height with raft.

*UPDATE v2:

  • made the pieces wider to lock on the phone steadier

*UPDATE v3:

  • curve aesthetics
  • more allowance to inaccuracy

Post processing:
If you have a removable heated bed, after printing and installing the case on you phone, heat the bed to 70 degree Celsius, then remove the bed and place it on a table, press and rotate the back of your phone onto the heated bed with the case on. You will end up having a very flat case.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4*0.1

Notes:

Recommended to print on raft for much more accurate edge than brim.

comments.text: Thanks. I don't think it's possible to edit this case to fit another phone. It's much easier to start from scratch and build your own. You can refer to the dimensions in this case.
comments.author: avipars

description.text:
I really liked the idea of a light in my enclosure that wasn't attached to the enclosure so that quick and easy removal of the enclosure for maintenance wasn't a hassle.
I found this one which I liked and printed, then realized the issues with it; scaling and the extruder would hit it at full height. I used it as a basis to create my own and add height to it.

After printing the LED strip holder needs to be glued together. I just used some leftover 12v LED tape strip that I had from a different project. I wired it into a spare 12v output on my power supply and control the light with a relay switch that is controlled through GPIO output via Octoprint on a raspberry pi.

update
I added some new fasteners to attach it to the ceiling of the enclosure and ditched the arms. New stl added for the fasteners.

This is a custom project I made for a friend named Sean. Sean reached out to me to help him build a custom solution to control the vent in his room using Amazon Echo. The problem he's trying to solve is to control the atmosphere in his room without changing the climate of the entire house. Sean is currently in a wheelchair and can't get up to reach his vent, that's why this custom solution will work great for him.

Here is the original message I received from Sean:
https://www.instagram.com/p/BN8SD54gQPf/?taken-by=4hackrr

The source codes for this project will be posted on GitHub.com soon.

You can watch a video here:
https://www.instagram.com/p/BQRIF2JA-Mu/?taken-by=4hackrr

Do you like the feeling of impending doom? You know, that feeling that you get right before your family is eaten by Titans? If so, then this is the model for you! I've designed him to hang on the back of my computer monitor.

Head: I've included files with and without built-in supports.

Hands: There are two sets of hand files. The first hang onto 20mm (3/4") material. The second, "AoT Hands Long", will get you around 25mm (1"). Again, I've included files with and without built-in supports.

Bracket: The bracket should just slot into the underside of the head. At the bottom of the bracket I've left some notches. Clip them off as needed for leveling.

author: dpromano76

description.text:
I designed this battery grid to use 14 and 12 gauge copper household wire and have the wire fit down inside the surface for protection (flat surface without wires protruding). The wires can run along the battery ends or between the batteries in either direction. Running wire between the batteries is needed for adding the thin fuse wires. Its intended to make a 12v battery that can be connected with others as needed, as most projects use intervals of 12 volts ( 12v, 24V, 36V, 48V, 72V). This will be a 3s battery with 10 batteries in each bank, 30 batteries total. There is a 3mm gap between batteries for good air cooling.
Of course you will need 2 of these to make one battery. I printed it with 0 infill and 0.8mm shell, and it is strong enough

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1qYZmurDs0I

description.text: This is a multi-wrench that looks like a fish skeleton. It incorporates 21 distinct wrenches for metric and SAE nuts, 3 flat screwdrivers, a serrated cutting edge, a can opener, a wire breaker, a centerfinding tool, and a lanyard loop hole.

Material should be 1/16-1/8" stainless steel, with cutting by laser or water-jet. Fishbone wrenches are designed to cut from bar stock with minimal waste as shown.  If you have DXF scaling issues, the fish's "eye" hexagon should be 0.326" from flat to flat.

description.text:
This is a ground station option for the connex prosight.

It is designed to use the existing 'clip' to attach the connex to the printed mount.

The mount has a bay for an immersion av powerbox, + space for two batteries.

The setup is a little wastefull of the av inputs as the connex does not use these - but never mind. It is meant to provide a redundant power supply, allowing you to feed power to your goggles and the prosight.

This is a collection of Wizard of Oz lithopanes, based on photographs from the movie. I made these as decorations for a school community event. Small versions of the group photo were given away as souvenirs to the attendees.

print_settings.Notes:: I didn't really need supports, brims, or rafts. The leg printed just fine as long as you have good bed adhesion. The tabs are small enough that they printed fine for me without any supports.

description.text:
Recently, my keyboard leg broke. Instead of buying a new keyboard, I decided to print a replacement leg. These fit an HP KU-1156 keyboard, but I suspect they may work for most keyboard models/brands.

There is a Left and a Right leg, depending on which one you need.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed these with the leg standing up. The straight edge which has the tabs is on the print bed, and the angled/beveled edge is pointing up.

I didn't really need supports, brims, or rafts. The leg printed just fine as long as you have good bed adhesion. The tabs are small enough that they printed fine for me without any supports.

author: dpromano76

print_settings.Notes:: 5 x 5.2mm washer

description.text: This is my own design of a clock incorporating some curves into the design. The turning gears create an interesting illusion as the curves move past each other at different speeds. All the clock internals are visible from the outside making it an intriguing time piece to look at as the time ticks on and on.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

All the bigger parts are printed with these settings. Parts like the supports, washers and axles are printed with 100% infill. There is a 0.2mm tolerance worked into the design.

Print the gears:

  • Motor gear
  • Seconds gear
  • Seconds to minutes reduction gear
  • Minutes gear
  • Minutes to hours reduction gear
  • Hour gear

Print the clock hands:

  • Seconds hand
  • Minutes hand
  • Hour hand

Print the parts for the main body:

  • Back plate
  • Face plate
  • 4 x support
  • 2 x support 2
  • Reduction gears support plate

Print the extras:

  • 5 x 5.2mm washer
  • 1 x 7.2mm washer
  • 1 x 9.2mm washer
  • Reduction gears axle

Face plate finishing

I spray-painted the face plate with a hammered metal finish. To make the numerals stand out, I sponged some black paint onto them.

Annotated view Assembly

Assembly is fairly simple, I've added a drawing to show where all the parts go. Glue is used only to keep the 6 support posts in place as well as the reduction gears support plate. Do not use glue to keep the clock hands in place, they were designed to have a snug fit but still be able to move them manually to set the time.

Motor

I used a stepper motor that I got from an old scanner that I disassembled. The base plate is currently designed according to the shape of that motor. I've made the link to the design on OnShape available for you to be able to adapt the back plate. I'm more than willing to help out in case you need a custom design.
The design was done using OnShape. Here is a link to the public design. Curve clock design

description.text:
I made this quick model for my dungeons and dragons group. The tree is a quick easy print for any capable FDM type printer. Very versatile, can be dead spooky trees, can be spring/fall etc. Just add some fluff or foliage (brushed yarn fluff from pet comb or colored cotton balls etc).
This was Printed on my mono select mini printer, at a low resolution, with light infill and a quick speed. It took 28 minutes to print (cura said it would take 18 minutes though) and weighs at 3 grams. I did not need supports to print this but it would improve quality for some of the limbs. I add brushed yarn fluff for the leaves and it can hold a regular sized mini figurine as well if the base is not too big. (used solutech white 1.75 printer filament)

title: Ant weight wedge battlebot using VEX 393 motors

description.text: This is a 1lb U.S. ant weight wedge bot that uses VEX 393 motors with 2 pieces of 5 hole aluminum plate cut to 5X3. I used the lexan from last years VEX IQ game field to keep from having to buy some. In order to keep this at/below 16 ounces you will need a 2S 450mah or lighter battery and some lite flite or other brand foam wheels. If you remove the circuit board with the ptc's from the motors like I did make sure you use different wires from the motor so you do not get them mixed up with a motor that may get put on a VRC competition robot. I used a FlySky 6 channel receiver with some inexpensive brushed motor controllers and elevon mixing on the transmitter. The robot I printed will compete in March of 2017 so I will follow this up with how it performed.

Printer:

Home Built Core-XY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

40%

Proving the power of Tinkercad

I actually designed this using a free Tinkercad account to prove the ability of this simple cloud based CAD program. I obviously did not have the tools I am used to in Fusion 360 or Solidworks, but I could teach a 10-12 year old how to design this part in about 30 minutes.

title: Top Mounting Rolling Spool Holder for Maker Select

description.text:
This is really a remix / mashup of two fine designs. I wanted the friction-less roller that was top mounting for my Maker Select Printers. There is a really nice snap on filament guide designed by AndyShen that I used to join to the bottom of the Rolling Spool Holder (remix by JustinLimonges).

This is the result and I am very happy. Simply snap in the 4 standard Skateboard Bearings (nice fit) then snap it to the top of your Mono Price Maker Select (or Wanhao Duplicator). Snap on the back and pull down. You can then slide the mounts to fit the width of each of your filament spools.

Maker Select

I used 80% infill -- but there is probably no reason you can't do less. I also printed with 1.2 thickness on all walls.

title: Small Lab Supply based on DP30V5A
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to build a small bench/lab supply for my electronics work and decided to try using the DP30V5A adjustable supply controller from Banggood.com:

http://www.banggood.com/DP30V5A-Voltage-Converter-LCD-Constant-Voltage-Current-Step-down-Programmable-Power-Supply-p-1041746.html?rmmds=search

This a great little unit and it costs less than $32. It does need an external power source, but I had an old 24V 5A supply handy.

You will also need:
40mmx10mm 24V fan (The fan voltage depends on your input supply voltage)
Sermos/Anderson power pole connector for input power.
Banana jacks for output connection.
Power switch
7 #2x3/8" screws
Some wire, etc..

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm 2 extra shells

Infill:

30%

Assemble the case

Use thick CA glue to assemble the parts of the case.

Glue the front panel to the base first, then the top.

I found that I had to sand the bottom of the front panel a bit to get it to sit flush at the top.

Getting a smooth finish

I decided to try for a very smooth finish on the case so I used Bondo auto body putty to fill in the gaps between the "noodles". (This works for PLA, but not with ABS.)

I did this two times and wet sanded after each applictaion had dried. First with 240 grit then 400 grit.

It worked better than I had hoped, after spray painting it looked great!

I used Krylon 2X spay paint.

After Bondo and sanding, but before painting. After painting Final assembly

I wired up the parts first and then installed them into the case.

First install the banana jacks.
Then install the power switch.
Then run the wires to the DP30V5A thru the opening and connect them. After that insert the unit into the front panel.

I mounted the fan to the back with 4-40 nuts and bolts.

I added a fuse block help on with a 6-32 bolt and nut. If you want to do that you will need to drill a hole for it.

The next thing was to mount the Sermos/Anderson power pole connector for the input power. It is hels in place by a #2x3/8" screw and some thick CA.

The final step is to use 6 #2x3/8 screws to hold the back panel on.

Ready to screw on the back panel

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 LED light bar

description.text:
I needed to add LED lighting to my Prusa i3 Mk2 in order to see the bed with Octoprint and a camera better. I designed this set of two brackets and a single bar for LED strip lights that I had left over from another project. The exact lights I used are these:

Bang good non-waterproof LED strip light, 12V

The LED bar can be printed on the Prusa bed by rotating 45 degrees. The bar and brackets are circular so that the angle of the strip can be adjusted to an extent, to best light the bed. The lights can be mounted with a single bracket, but at least two provides greatest stability. They were printed using the standard PLA settings that come with the printer. NOTE: Some LED strip lights can get quite hot over time, so consider printing in PETG if needed. I'd also recommended gluing the edges of the LED strip into the bar with superglue or epoxy, as the sticky-backing isn't usually that great.

The brackets should be mounted to the BACK of the printer, in order to remain out of the way of the print head when it's raised to the top.

For my own setup, I used the two remaining wire connectors in the Mk2 power supply to provide the 12V power to the LEDs. This required taking apart the bottom of the existing power supply, so make this modification at your own risk! I also added an in-line switch to turn the lights on or off separately from the printer. Using a separate 12V power supply for the LEDs could easily accomplish the same thing.

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

20%

Notes:

No need for supports or rafts, brackets should fit snug to the metal bar at the top of the printer.

SLR Sky Tracker Instructions
2/18/2017
B. Gonzales

Bill of Material in PDF

Parts sourced from McMaster Car, Amazon, Stepper Online

Uses PrintRBot Revision F Board. Source and executable included. Instructions on compilation and downloading are available online. Uses Audrino 1.0.5 R2 for the AT90USB1286

Firmware steps at 18.07 steps per second (Simple PID loop in the firmare to achieve floating point step count)

There is 1 Switch for Forwards and 1 Switch for backwards at max rate (To reset the position to start).
These are triggered in the firmware by grounding Port Pins E0 and E1 (Pin #33 and #34 on U6). See Schematic:

http://reprap.org/wiki/File:Printrboard_RevF_Schematic150.png

These pins route to EXP2, You can solder to the holes or install a header. The pin order is not defined by the schematic, and is wrong on the board print. I suggest you ohm out from U6 to this header to verify the correct pin.

Have Fun!

comments.text: So Far, I've been able to use it up to about 5 minutes with 150mm Zoom. Could go much longer with wider focal lengths. Rule of thumb without a tracking scope is to divide 500 by the focal length. This give you the rough number of seconds you can track the sky. This method does much better than that.

This is a telescopic A/C vent for NA or NB Mazda Miatas (it will replace the eyeball in the stock A/C vents. All parts were modelled in Solidworks. I was tired of having vents that couldn't be closed when they weren't in use, so I decided to make new ones.

I recommend printing this with ABS. I tested the parts with PLA, and they warped when I put the car's heat on. Also, PLA and other poor temperature resistance materials will not be able to withstand the temperature of the car in the sun regardless.

To make one vent, you will need to print:
1 x Shell
1 x Pushrod (I recommend a high infill for this part due to poor layer adhesion with ABS)
1 x Nub
8 x Linkage (or two sets of 4)
4 x Flap (or one set of 4)

To assembleeach vent, you will need:
8 x M2x6 (or longer)screws
8 x M2 nuts
4 x toothpicks (or any other straight rod that will fit in the ~2.4mm holes in the shell)
Superglue (or acetone for acetone welding the nub to the pushrod if you are using ABS).

Use the M2 screws and nuts to connect the flaps to the linkages, and then the linkages to the pushrod. Use two linkages per flap - the bolt and nut will be touching different linkages each. This will ensure that the bolt and nut do not become looser with time as you continue to use the vent. Ensure that the connection is centered (the surfaces you are connecting are offset so that the connection itself may be centered. Then, I used toothpicks to hold the flaps along the holes in the shell, and cut them so that they would not protrude. Then, I used superglue to keep them locked onto the shell. After this, I generally sand the surface to make it smooth, and then repaint that portion with the inside taped off.

I printed the parts with rigid.ink ABS. To give the vent a tighter fit, I added a small piece of Velcro (the soft, fuzzy portion) to stop the vent from drooping, since I was also having that problem with my vents as it was.

I recommend printing the flaps and shell with support on. I printed the flaps upright so that the curved surfaces had a nicer-looking finish.

author: Renngarage

description.text:
Recycled Prusa: What was becomes another.

I wanted to add a laser cutter/engraver to my shop and decided it would make a good design challenge based on recycling a Prusa Mendel - Essentially a frame of 5/16” threaded rod and 8mm rod with LMU88 bearings. The CAD models had to be simple to print, make what you can, buy what you absolutely must, and source locally. Ultimately this project is a primer for building gen III of my 3D printer and a larger gen II laser of many watts. As such I’m sharing an ‘as-is’ , ‘it got me to operational’ dump of the project STL’s, sanding and part prep will be required.

Firmware is Marlin configured for CoreXY. It was helpful to set a dummy thermistor value as this allows using the print bead and hot-end outputs as switches from gcode (M104 S100 and M140 S100, send S0 to turn off). The fans and laser power supply are switched, as usual fan PWM modulates the laser through M106.

Gcode generation is either by Jtech Inkscape plugin or 305 Engineering’s raster generator. For engraving PCB’s I ended up modifying 305’s code, borrowing a page from Jtech. The first change was having laser off moves run at full speed, since acceleration is handled in firmware this shaves a lot of time off the job. The second change was to have a pause when turing the laser on or off as to allow the edges of the burn to be more defined, 200ms was enough. Finally adding pre and post geode safe the machine when done and get in position. I’ll see about cleaning up my notes and getting the code posted. Perhaps in the future with some better python skills I can add some features.

title: MSFFB2 Joystick Extension
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a printable extension for the "Microsoft Sidewinder Force Feedback 2" joystick.
The extension extends the stick approximately 11 cm.

Installation

Dismantle the handle and remove it from the mount.
Remove the spring from the chamber on the mount. (Make sure to reattach the chamber lid after removing spring.)
Turn the base on its head, and unscrew the screws to remove the cover. (There are also screws under all the rubber pads.)
Remove the 11-pin plug from the largest circuit board, and push it through the neck of the stick. It is a tight fit, so instead of pulling the cord try pushing with a thin pencil or a screwdriver.
Fit the 11-pin cable that goes from the handle components through the extension using the same technique.
Take the extension cable. attach it to the circuitboard, and feed the other end through the neck of the joystick. You can now screw the cover back on.
Turn the stick around and attach the cable from the handle components to the extension cable. Push the connection into the neck of the joystick, not into the extension. This is alot simpler.
Push the extension down unto the neck on the base, and clip on the cover to secure the extension.
Take the spring that you removed from the chamber on the neck and place it in the chamber on the extension. put the lid on.
Push the cable into the slot on the top of the extension. Put the potentiometer on top to secure the cables.
Put the left side of the handle on the stick. Make sure the spring hits its slot, and place the components where they need to be. (Push buttons 3 and 4 out from the inside of the handle pieces to fit the top component.) Make sure the potensiometer is held in place by the handle piece.
Attach the right side of the handle and screw them together.
Have a coffee, and give yourself a high five!

Safety information and precautions

Mounting the extension means you have to open the joystick base and detatch the cable that goes through the neck. Be careful when working with the components on the inside, and make sure that the power cord and USB is unplugged before opening the stick.

Be careful not to touch the power supply (the smallest circuit board near the power cord). This board is loose after you unscrew the cover, so make sure the joystick base is upside down at all times. It is smart to dismantle the handle first. This allows you to place the stick on its head.

Skills and knowledge about basic electronics is an advantage. If you feel unsure about opening your stick, have someone with the required skills help you. I will take no responsibility for any damage to the joystick, or injury caused by installing this extension.

Requirements

You need the Force Feedback 2 joystick to fit this extension. It may also work with other variants of Microsoft joysticks, if they have the same handle mount.
You also need an extension cable to reach all the way through (The cable has a JST 2.0mm PH 11-pin plug), or you can extend the existing cable if you have the soldering skills.

description.text:
This is a fully printable 1.75mm bowden extruder.

The release lever allows for easy insertion of the filament. The filament tension is adjusted via the recessed cap screw at the rear.

There is no top or bottom, the extruder can be mounted to the stepper motor for either left or right hand operation.

I put a piece of foam in the filter along with a couple drops of mineral oil. This cleans and lubricates the filament. The filter is press fitted to the body. You insert it and give a slight twist to seat it. If you put foam in the filter make sure you push the filament through the filter and clean any piece of foam stuck to the tip before mating to the extruder body. I printed up a bunch of filters and leave them on the roll of filament in storage. It, at least for me, acts as the filament holder and helps prevent the filament from getting tangled.

Gear teeth are 11 and 45 for a ratio of 4.090909...

The adapter plate is what I use on my custom Quad CoreXY. I use a different plate for my Mendel. This is the piece that may (probably) need to be redesigned to fit your printer.

I provided two parts list. One PDF where the hyperlinks don't work. The other is a Microsoft Word doc with working (I hope) hyperlinks. The list shows the bulk cost that I paid for the parts. Purchasing smaller quantities will save money.

I am able to print the release lever without any support material where the idler bearing sits. Your results may vary depending on the print quality of your printer.

Printer:

Custom Designed CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I've had good results printing these parts with the first layer at .3mm and the remainder at .2mm.

1. The stepper motor mounting holes on the body sections are printed closed off for print quality. I use a 3mm finger drill to open the holes the rest of the way.
  2. Depending on the print quality you may need a 3mm washer above and/or below the bearing in the release lever. Normally one washer/spacer is all that's needed.
  3. The release lever is designed to hold the plastic Bowen clip directly.

I used DAZ Hexagon to design my CoreXY printer,including the extruder.
The extruder gears were initially designed using FreeCad but I had to tweak them in Hexagon.

comments.text: Bolt, gear, washer, nut, hobbed insert.  Loctite on the hobbed insert.  With the body screwed down to the stepper you can press the release lever and see the hobbed insert.  The narrowest part of  the insert should be exactly in the center on the body - It should be aligned to the seam between the two body halves.  If it is not you may need to add or remove washers.

title: Magnetic latch for Lulzbot Mini enclosure (DrazzticAction/Tabsynth)

description.text: This is a replacement latch for the Drazzticaction/Tabsynth enclosure for a Lulzbot Mini

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard settings in Cura

Notes:

While I was reprinting the hinges and clips for the enclosure in Lulzbot Green ABS (Just for the lulz of it....), I thought I'd change the latch that holds the door shut. The original one was a bit hard to turn, so I decided to make one that latches with magnets.

There is a small bridge/overhang in the piece that holds the nut. But it still came out fine without using support material.

You can reuse the original bolt and nut. The magnets I used are 6mm in diameter and 4mm high neodymium magnets. I think the holding strength was N45. Don't remember exactly as I bought these a long time ago, in a galaxy, far, far away... :-)

I used to cyanoacrylate (superglue) to glue the magnets in place. Make sure you align the magnets correctly otherwise it will push the door open instead of holding it shut:-)
I did not use superglue to glue the magnetholder onto the acrylic but some thin double-sided tape. Superglue tends to leave stains and I want to be able to replace it if needed.

Well, that's it! And thanks to DrazzticAction for a great enclosure! Other spare parts can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/DrazzticAction/designs

*EDIT: Probably needless to say, but you have to rotate the parts in Cura so they are flat on the bed... For some reason they export in a different orientation in Fusion 360. Picture added.

description.text: This is a very quick and dirty spool holder for my Monoprice Ultimate. I really dislike the side mounted spool holder and just wanted something that would be quick to make. I had the wooden dowels already here (3/16), they are under a dollar at walmart. They cut down on the print time and are longer than the bed on the ultimate so win win. I spent all of 15 mins in tinkercad cranking the design out. It does print out really close to exact. I did just do a couple passes with a file on the bottom pieces and just like two times around the holes on the top with a dremel to get a perfect friction fit. Overall it was just under 2 hours including print time and design time from start to finish.

title: Drone Stand for Dromida Kodo HD

description.text:
This is a stand I designed for my Dromida Kodo HD. The drone is put on the stand by sliding it onto the stand through the battery holder. There are also slots for the battery and controller. It has supports so that the stand is balanced when taking things off it or putting them back on.

Edit: added a file for the assembled stand but with the battery holder separate because getting support material out of that thing would be a pain. You can glue the holder on after the print.

I think it came out pretty well. Here are my thoughts:

  • The battery holder is a good size. It's big enough that the battery can be slid in and out easily but small enough to fit the battery well.
  • I must have measured wrong on the controller holder, because the controller doesn't quite fit in. I made the slot bigger in the design but I didn't feel like reprinting it so the pictures I gave of the finished product have the small version.
  • The struts on the controller holder do a great job of balancing the stand, despite looking as if they will come off if you move them a little (this is probably due to my lack of gluing skills).
  • I like the minimalist look of it, but still wish I didn't need those struts under the controller slot.

Printer

Printrbot Play

Supports

No*

Resolution

N/A

Infill

I used 15%, as I do for most of my prints.

*If you use the assembled file, you will probably supports. But if you are OK with just using the pieces file and gluing everything together later, you will not need any supports.

This is my design for a z-axis for a lemoncurry like DLP printer. I call it sloth DLP reprap for now. That will propably change ;-) You will need to mount an acrylic stage to the aluminium angle. For more information on lemoncurry visit https://code.google.com/p/lemoncurry/wiki/main
or

This is the third iteration of design and there may follow further, when i get the other parts for my printer. You can get an impression what I am planning in the first image. I am planning to document the progress here and on my blog when I get the time: http://blog.krieft.de/2012/04/11/dlp-drucker/

BOM:
  • 2 lm8uu + wire straps
  • 2 smooth rods 8mm
  • 2 threaded rods M8
  • 5 M8 screw nut and some wahsers
  • 1 aluminium angle (see image, i tapped some of the holes)
  • ~ 11 M4 screws with washers and nuts
  • 1 nema17 stepper motor
  • 1 coupling for stepper motor
  • 2 Distance screws (don't know if that is the correct name)
    • If the assembly is not clear to you feel free to ask here, I will then add more instructions here.

title: Side Spoolholder and Filamentmanager for Replicator, Duplicator and similary Printers

description.text:
Die hinteren Spulenhalterungen sind leider etwas unpraktisch, da man nicht sehen kann in wie weit das Filament aufgebraucht ist. Auch ist der Wechsel laestig, wenn man den Drucker an einer Wand stehen hat.  
Mit derer Erweiterung ist es nun moeglich, die Spulen stabil und sichtbar auf einer Seite des Druckers zu verlagern.  
Das Filament wird sauber durch die optimierte Halterung gefuehrt. Die Spulen koennen leicht gewechselt werden.   
Das Umbau-Set sollte fuer alle baugleichen Drucker passen. Ich habe diese an einem Duplicator 4 und an einem Creator installiert.  
Benoetigt werden noch je Set 2 x M4 Schrauben sowie eine etwas laengere M3 Schraube fuer die Filamentfuehrung. Ein Gewindeschneider (M4) wird fuer das Rohr benoetigt. Es muessen keine Loecher in das Gehaeuse des Druckers gebohrt werden!

description.text: This thing can be used to place two 80mm fans wherever you need them. I find it usefull for activities like soldering, but also when testing things that get hot etc...

Machineree Paddle Switch

This paddle switch is a simple addition to any regular toggle light switch and provides mechanical advantage and easy access to otherwise small switches located on machines. Users can buy a common single or double pole switch at the hardware store for a few dollars along with some bolts and have a working paddle switch in minutes! The design allows the user to 3D print or CNC (or export to 2D for templates) linkages to fit their needs and have a simple paddle switch that turns the machine on and off. NOTE: the switch is installed upside down! Make note of this on the machine when installing and make sure all power is unplugged! Before testing, your switch should be in the "UP" position as off.

Required:

  • ¼ - 20 x 4" Bolts (3)
  • ¼ - 20 x 2" Bolts (1)
  • ¼ - 20 Nylon Lock Insert Nuts (4)
  • 6 x ¾" Screws (6) -- if building paddle
  • 6 - 32 x ½" Pan Head Machine Screws (2)
  • Light Switch [110v/220v] (1)

Print:

  • Switch Plate x1
  • Hinge Bracket x2
  • Short Linkage x4
  • Long Linkage x2
  • Spacer x2
  • Paddle x1 (If not building out of stock--you can now print)

More Info: http://machineree.com/#paddle

Complete Build Instructions: http://machineree.com/paddleguide.html

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eGOtbY8-jVY

description.text: This is for growing plants using 1" grow cubes. I use the cubes upside down so that they seat in the planter. The cutter is for cutting a 1" square hole in styrofoam boards. Is it best to go from both sides as otherwise it will leave a jagged hole. Just pound the cutter through using a hammer. The 1" insert fits in the hole and produces a clean seat to place the grow cube into. There is also a 2" insert in case you have boards that already have a 2" hole cut in them (2" net cups are a common size). Print using 100% fill and use food safe plastic. A dark color (for UV resistance) and something that blocks out the reds and blues that algae needs is advisable. I use dark green. I have successfully used PETG and HIPS and they have lasted 2 years outside with no problem.

A very simple Z-axis leveler.

You can customize it!!!
